title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
Microsoft agreed to buy Activision in an all-cash deal valued at about $75 billion, using its largest acquisition by far to grab a videogame heavyweight that has been roiled by claims of workplace misconduct.

---

Goldman Sachs said it boosted its pay by 33% last year, sending the bank to a quarterly profit decline as the war for talent plays out across Wall Street.

---

Crude prices rose to their highest level since the 2014 shale-induced oil crash, a milestone in a rally that is gathering momentum as geopolitical tensions threaten to knock supply.

---

U.S. stock indexes fell and bond yields hit two-year highs. The S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow slid 1.8%, 2.6% and 1.5%, respectively. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note ticked up to 1.866%.

---

AT&T and Verizon agreed to not turn on some 5G signals near airport runways, a temporary concession to address air-safety concerns that have already prompted international airlines to cancel some U.S.-bound flights.

---

Gilead said that a network of little-known drug suppliers and distributors sold illicit and potentially dangerous fake versions of its HIV medicines.

---

Exxon said it set a goal to reduce or offset greenhouse-gas emissions from its operations to zero by 2050.

---

Citigroup is nearing a sale of its retail-banking franchise in Taiwan to DBS for around $2 billion.
